title-group.article-title: An Overview of Developmental Disorders Leading to Dystocia in Cattle

aff.institution: School of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences, University of Nebraska‐Lincoln

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Dystocia due to developmental disorders causing foetal malformation is a significant challenge in bovine obstetrics, often resulting in severe birth complications. This narrative review provides an updated overview of the most common congenital syndromes associated with dystocia in cattle, emphasising both their clinical implications and underlying causes. Congenital disorders such as schistosoma reflexum, perosomus elumbis, arthrogryposis, hydrocephalus, anasarca and embryonic duplication are reviewed in detail, along with their impact on the course of calving. While the management of dystocia due to foetal malformations has remained relatively constant over time—mainly involving assisted delivery, foetotomy or caesarean section—our understanding of their aetiologies has advanced considerably. In addition to environmental factors, such as viral infections during gestation, genetic causes may also be implicated. Genetic aetiologies, including dominant de novo mutations and recessively inherited alleles, such as single nucleotide variants, larger structural variants or aneuploidies, have been identified as the cause of some of these congenital defects. This review provides a comprehensive resource on dystocia due to developmental disorders, offering veterinarians updated knowledge to guide clinical decision making and improve outcomes for both the dam and the calf.

p.mixed-citation: Agerholm, J. S., C.Drögemüller, D. J.Steffen, and J. G. P.Jacinto. 2025. “An Overview of Developmental Disorders Leading to Dystocia in Cattle.” Reproduction in Domestic Animals60, no. S3: e70083. 10.1111/rda.70083.40899133PMC12406085

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Dystocia due to foetal malformation is an important aspect of bovine obstetrics and has featured in veterinary obstetrical textbooks for more than a century (Arthur 1964; Baumeister 1844; Benesch 1957; Noakes et al. 2019; Oppermann 1922; Richter et al. 1912; Richter and Götze 1993; Williams 1909). Some of these congenital syndromes have become classic examples of what are sometimes referred to as “foetal monsters,” as bovine veterinarians have encountered the same syndromes again and again over many decades while attending bovine dystocia cases. These classic examples include congenital syndromes such as schistosoma reflexum (Figure 1), perosomus elumbis, arthrogryposis, anasarca and hydrocephalus. Despite their sporadic and low incidence, developmental disorders pose a significant obstetric challenge as many are associated with severe dystocia that requires veterinary assistance. Furthermore, these cases frequently result in conditions that are life‐threatening for the dam, in addition to foetal loss (Knight 1996).

caption.p: Historical illustration of a bovine schistosoma reflexum case. Throughout the history of veterinary obstetrics, schistosoma reflexum has been an important cause of dystocia in cattle. Adapted from Harms' Lehrbuch der tierärztlichen Geburtshilfe published in 1912 (Richter et al. 1912).

sec.p: Dystocia due to developmental disorders may have several causes, but it usually occurs due to either foetomaternal disproportion caused by enlargement of the foetus or parts of the foetus, or develops because the calf is presented in an abnormal posture. Each case should be handled on an individual basis, taking into account the welfare of the dam as well as that of the foetus. Many dams carrying a malformed foetus give birth at or near the expected time of parturition and the calves are generally alive at this time. A malformed foetus should therefore be handled humanely and with the same care as a normally developed calf during major interventions such as performing foetotomy or correcting abnormal posture, e.g., hip flexion posture (“breech presentation”). The attending veterinarian must decide which intervention is the most appropriate for the individual case. Some advice on how to manage the most common congenital syndromes is given here in relation to their presentation below.

While methods to manage dystocia due to developmental disorders have not changed significantly for decades and generally consist of caesarean section, complete or partial foetotomy, or forced traction after resolving the issue causing dystocia, our knowledge about the aetiology of bovine congenital syndromes has increased considerably. Bovine foetal malformations and congenital anomalies may be due to infections, where viral pathogens play a major role (Agerholm et al. 2015; Agerholm and Wernike 2022), or non‐infectious causes, with the number of known genetic causes increasing rapidly. The Online Mendelian Inheritance in Animals (OMIA) database has recorded almost 300 single‐gene‐related conditions in cattle, and of these, at least one likely causal variant has been identified for around 200 non‐syndromic or syndromic developmental disorders (Nicholas and Tammen 2022). Although not all recognised inherited disorders are associated with dystocia, our knowledge of the genetic background of disorders that do cause dystocia is continuously increasing. Table 1 lists congenital syndromes associated with dystocia that have a known genetic cause, including spontaneous dominant de novo mutations, autosomal recessive alleles and aneuploidies.

caption.p: Bovine developmental disorders associated with dystocia and with a known genetic cause.

td.italic: FLNA, ACTL6A, MLLT1, MAST3, MBTPS2, GLG1, DYNC1LI1, PPP2R2B, UBP1, SCAF8

tr.td: Congenital U‐shaped dorsal retroflexion of the spine, exposure of abdominal viscera due to thoracoschisis and abdominoschisis, arthrogryposis and ankylosis of the pelvic limbs, and occasionally palatoschisis and other defects

Congenital arthrogryposis or joint contracture of multiple joints, reduced body weight, severe torticollis and kyphoscoliosis, mild lordosis, joints with fibro‐osseous ankyloses, palatoschisis, lateral deviation of viscerocranium and narrowed thorax
Congenital arthrogryposis of all limbs, severe scoliosis, stocky head, macroglossia impaired tooth eruption, cleft palate and upper lip, omphalocele and corneal clouding

Congenital difficult quadrupedal stance, tremor, ataxia, only backward movement with hypermetria in pelvic limbs and tip‐toe‐standing of the forelimbs, increased muscle tone in limbs, reduced spinal reflexes and sensibility in limbs

Congenital flattening of the neurocranium associated with compression of the brain hemispheres and caudal displacement of the occipital lobes, midbrain and cerebellum causing either partial or complete herniation of the medulla oblongata and cerebellum into the first segments of the cervical vertebral canal and elongation of the occipital lobes. Spina bifida and arthrogryposis
DYNC1H1, partial monosomy of chromosome 2 and trisomy 12
Congenital diffuse severe subcutaneous oedema, accumulation of fluids in the body cavities (anasarca) and a dysplasia of the lymphatic system in addition to pulmonary hypoplasia or aplasia
Hydrallantois characterised by an excessive accumulation of fluid within the allantoic cavity. Allantoic fluid volume in affected cows may exceed 100 L
Sakamoto et al. (2020); Sasaki et al. (2016)
Congenital occipital cranioschisis with meningocele, with or without lipoma, myolipoma or teratoma and polymelia

sec.title: Congenital Syndromes
sec.p: A wide range of congenital developmental disorders cause dystocia in cattle. A complete overview of all developmental disorders associated with dystocia in cattle would be exhaustive and because new syndromes are continuously being recognised, such an overview would quickly become incomplete. The focus in this review is therefore on congenital developmental disorders that have, over decades or centuries, been recognised as a cause of dystocia.

sec.title: Schistosoma Reflexum
sec.p: Schistosoma reflexum (OMIA:000890‐9913) is a congenital syndrome characterised by U‐shaped dorsal retroflexion of the spine, thoracoabdominoschisis associated with the exposure of internal organs, arthrogryposis and ankylosis of the pelvic limbs, and occasionally palatoschisis and other defects. A classic case of schistosoma reflexum is shown in Figure 2a. Necropsy and genomic analysis of affected bovine foetuses have shown that schistosoma reflexum is not a specific disorder but rather a group of malformations sharing the characteristic lesions (disease prototype), i.e., dorsal retroflexion of the spine and thoracoabdominoschisis. This disease prototype can develop due to dominant de novo mutations in a wide range of genes, either occurring in the developing embryo or inherited from a germline mosaic parent (Jacinto, Häfliger, et al. 2024). An autosomal recessive allele causing schistosoma reflexum has been suggested for Holsteins based on familial relationships between a number of schistosoma reflexum cases (Citek 2012), but genomic analyses of 23 other cases did not identify a shared genomic region of identity‐by‐descent, nor homozygous or compound heterozygous variants in individual genes associated with schistosoma reflexum (Jacinto, Häfliger, et al. 2024). Genetic relationships between calves affected by the same congenital syndrome may occur simply by chance (Agerholm et al. 2001, 2004) due to the increased level of inbreeding in many cattle populations as a result of the extensive use of artificial insemination and embryo transfer of certain breeding lines. The mere identification of one or more common ancestors should therefore always be interpreted with caution and confirmed by genomic analysis, as it may be coincident rather than causal.

caption.p: Schistosoma reflexum. (a) This syndrome is mainly characterised by U‐shaped dorsal retroflexion of the spine and thoracoabdominoschisis. (b) Foetal intestinal loops protrude from the vulva if the foetus is presented with its visceral pole. Courtesy (b): E Andersen.

sec.p: A retrospective study of 6901 bovine dystocia cases attended by Australian veterinarians over a 20‐year period showed that schistosoma reflexum was the cause of dystocia in 1.3% of the cases (Knight 1996). Accurate population data on the prevalence of schistosoma reflexum have not been published, but recently Mee et al. (2024) estimated a 1:10,000 prevalence in live, aborted and stillborn calves, making schistosoma reflexum the most common congenital defect recorded by veterinary practitioners in Ireland.

Schistosoma reflexum‐affected foetuses are presented with either head and limbs or abdominal organs in the vagina or protruding from the vulva (Figure 2b), depending on which part of the foetus has entered the birth canal. The size of schistosoma reflexum‐affected foetuses varies considerably. Data from the Danish genetic disease surveillance revealed an average body weight of 25.2 kg (18.1–32.5 kg; n = 7). Depending on the proportions of the maternal pelvic inlet and foetal presentation and size, some affected foetuses might be deliverable by careful manipulation. Knight (1996) reported that 56.7% were released by foetotomy, 25.6% by caesarean section and only 3.3% by simple traction. Slaughter or euthanasia of the dam was performed in 14.4% of cases, mainly due to a poor prognosis (e.g., in case of emphysematous foetus and intoxication) (Knight 1996).

The ease with which schistosoma reflexum can be diagnosed in a parturient animal depends on the presentation of the foetus. A diagnosis is most likely if foetal viscera are visible, but other body wall defects should be ruled out by careful palpation, and it is important to bear in mind that schistosoma reflexum is a disease prototype, so cases will not be identical. Recognising schistosoma reflexum when the head and limbs are presented can be more challenging, but careful palpation will reveal that it is not a case of twin pregnancy or transverse anterior presentation.

sec.title: Arthrogryposis
sec.p: Arthrogryposis is a developmental disorder of complex neurogenic or myopathic aetiology characterised by joint contracture and impaired intrauterine foetal movement. Joint contracture may affect one or more joints, one or more limbs, and joints of the appendicular or axial skeleton, or both. This interferes with the posture of the foetal limbs and head, depending on which joints are affected. This limb defect is often bilateral, but not always symmetrical (Agerholm, personal observation). Different expressions of arthrogryposis are shown in Figure 3.

caption.p: Congenital arthrogryposis. These four cases illustrate that congenital arthrogryposis has a wide morphological expression. The posture of the limbs is abnormal and, in some cases, the deviation of the head also causes dystocia. Ankylosis of one or more joints may hinder the correction of the abnormal posture. The cause of (a) and (b) was not determined, while (c) was due to a missense mutation in the gene CHRNB1 (Agerholm et al. 2016) and (d) due to foetal exposure to Schmallenberg virus (Agerholm and Wernike 2022).

sec.p: Arthrogryposis is associated with several inherited syndromes, including some mentioned in this review, such as perosomus elumbis. However, developmental disorders mainly characterised by arthrogryposis have also been reported. These primarily consist of syndromes with arthrogryposis of the joints of both the spine and limbs, known as arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC). Recessively inherited forms of AMC with independent causal variants have been reported in Belgian Blue (OMIA: 001953‐9913) (Sartelet et al. 2015), Red Danish dairy (OMIA: 002022‐9913) (Agerholm et al. 2016) and Angus cattle (OMIA: 002135‐9913) (Beever and Marron 2011). In addition, a single Holstein calf presenting with arthrogryposis distal type 1B due to a dominant de novo mutation has been reported (OMIA: 001978‐9913) (Wiedemar et al. 2015). Finally, a syndromic form of arthrogryposis and palatoschisis has been reported in Charolais cattle (OMIA: 000070‐9913), but the causal variant is still unknown (Duchesne and Eggen 2005).

Arthrogryposis may also have non‐genetic causes. Foetal infection with Orthobunyaviruses of the Simbu serogroup, such as Schmallenberg virus, Aino virus, Shuni virus, Peaton virus and Shamonda virus may cause arthrogryposis that is often associated with central nervous system malformations including hydranencephaly or porencephaly (Agerholm et al. 2015; Agerholm and Wernike 2022; O'Connor et al. 2024). Ingestion of teratogenic alkaloid‐containing plants (e.g., Lupinus caudatis and L. sericeus ) between Day 40 and 70 of gestation might also lead to the development of “crooked calf syndrome”, in which affected animals show skeletomuscular defects, such as arthrogryposis, torticollis, scoliosis and palatoschisis (Panter et al. 1999; Shupe et al. 1967). In addition, ingestion of selenium‐rich plants (e.g., Astragalus pectinatus and A. racemosus ) alone or in combination with a manganese deficiency might lead to the development of a form of arthrogryposis with kyphoscoliosis and palatoschisis (Leipold et al. 1974).

Arthrogryposis causes dystocia when the malformation interferes with the posture or presentation of the foetus. Cases must be assessed on an individual basis due to the wide phenotypic variability among cases, and the method of delivery should be decided on a case‐by‐case basis. If the calf is delivered alive, a clinical examination is important to ensure the absence of lesions other than arthrogryposis (e.g., palatoschisis and spina bifida) and to carefully evaluate the prognosis and treatment strategy if the calf is not to be humanely euthanised.

sec.title: Congenital Syndromic Chiari‐Like Malformation
sec.p: While congenital syndromic Chiari‐like malformation (CSCM) was only recently established as a specific disease entity (OMIA:000061‐9913) (Jacinto, Letko, et al. 2024), it has been reported for decades (Cho and Leipold 1977). Flattening of the calvarium causing caudal displacement of the brain with partial or complete herniation of the cerebellum through the foramen magnum (Chiari type II‐like lesion) and lumbar spina bifida are the primary lesions in this syndrome. These malformations lead to congenital bilateral pelvic limb arthrogryposis, which in combination with a breech presentation causes dystocia.

Most normally developed bovine foetuses (95%) are in anterior presentation at parturition, but during earlier stages of pregnancy, there is an equal ratio of foetuses in anterior and posterior presentation. The final orientation is adopted between gestation months five and six. After this time, the length of the foetus exceeds the width of the amnion, thus preventing further rotation (Noakes 2019).

Congenital syndromic Chiari‐like malformation and perosomus elumbis (see below) are associated with extensive dysplasia of pelvic and pelvic limb musculature, arthrogryposis with ankylosis and bone hypoplasia. Foetuses affected by these syndromes are often presented in bilateral hip flexion (Agerholm, personal observation). It is hypothesised that the hind part dysplasia interferes with the foetus' ability to be in anterior presentation, and due to the bilateral arthrogryposis with flexion of the tarsal joint (Figure 4a), the foetus is often delivered in breech presentation.

caption.p: Congenital syndromic Chiari‐like malformation (CSCM). (a) Typical case of CSCM, characterised by bilateral symmetrical pelvic limb arthrogryposis with flexion and ankylosis of the tarsal joints. Such foetuses are usually in breech presentation. (b) Spina bifida in the posterior lumbar spine is present as a sulcus. Palpation of this can facilitate the diagnosis of CSCM. Bar = 2 cm.

sec.p: Genomic analysis of 13 CSCM cases has revealed that multiple independent genetic variants may be associated with the development of this syndrome. As for schistosoma reflexum, CSCM is therefore a disease prototype. Development of CSCM in Holsteins can be due to a recessively inherited missense variant in individual genes or dominant de novo mutations. Analysis of whole genome sequencing data of > 5100 animals has identified that two CSCM‐related recessive alleles occur in two Holstein breeding lines. However, the same study also revealed that CSCM may develop due to a wide range of other genetic abnormalities, such as de novo occurring single nucleotide and larger structural variants, as well as chromosomal abnormalities, e.g., trisomy of chromosome 12 (Jacinto, Letko, et al. 2024).

In cases of breech presentation, CSCM should always be suspected and ruled out before attempting any correction of the malposture. Palpation and gentle manipulation of the pelvic limbs should be performed to rule out arthrogryposis and ankylosis. If the joints, especially the tarsal joint, are not flexible, palpation for the presence of a sulcus (spina bifida) in the dorsal midline just anterior to the os sacrum is recommended (Figure 4b). If CSCM cannot be ruled out, correction of the malposture in a living foetus is not recommended as there is a high risk of fracturing the long bones (Figure 5). If the foetus is dead, standard foetotomy for a foetus in breech position can be used to extract the pelvic limbs, followed by gentle extraction of the remaining part of the foetus. Otherwise, a caesarean section is recommended.

caption.p: Acute fracture of the left tibia associated with extensive haemorrhage. There is an increased risk of fracturing the long bones in cases of arthrogryposis. Arthrogryposis causes joint rigidity and bones may be fragile due to reduced limbic activity during foetal development. Transvaginal manipulation and attempts to correct the malposture must therefore be done with care.

sec.title: Perosomus Elumbis
sec.p: Perosomus elumbis is a congenital syndrome characterised by the absence of the lumbar, sacral and coccygeal spinal segments (OMIA: 000789‐9913). The absence of spinal cord segments results in extensive dysplasia of the hind part musculature, hypoplasia of the pelvis and pelvic limbs, and ankylotic arthrogryposis (Figure 6). The hind part of the foetus simply consists of an abdominal sac enclosing the viscera with hypoplastic pelvic limbs attached. Additional malformations may be present (Agerholm et al. 2014). The body weight of 12 full‐term cases submitted through the Danish surveillance programme ranged from 22.4 to 37.9 kg (average 29.4 kg).

caption.p: Perosomus elumbis. The anterior half of the foetus appears normally developed, while the posterior half consists of an abdominal skin “sac” that encloses the abdominal organs. The spine and spinal cord posterior to the thorax is not developed, and the pelvis and pelvic limbs are hypoplastic. Cases are often in breech presentation, but correction of the malpresentation may be achievable due to the high flexibility of the hind part.

sec.p: The aetiology of perosomus elumbis remains unclear, but as cases have occurred sporadically for more than 100 years—as evident from veterinary obstetrics textbooks (e.g., Richter et al. 1912)—and in a similar epidemiological pattern as for schistosoma reflexum and CSCM, we hypothesise that it may be caused by a range of dominant de novo single nucleotide or small indels mutations or aneuploidies either occurring in the developing conceptus or having been transmitted from a mosaic parent.

Foetuses affected by perosomus elumbis are often presented in bilateral hip flexion posture and must be differentiated from cases of CSCM by careful transvaginal palpation. Perosomus elumbis and CSCM cases share the same pelvic limb arthrogryposis and ankylosis, but the pelvic limbs of perosomus elumbis cases are more easily manipulated than those of CSCM cases due to the absence of posterior spinal segments. Perosomus elumbis cases also lack the dorsal midline sulcus (spina bifida), although this is not a consistent feature of CSCM. Depending on the foetal–maternal proportions and the mobility of the foetal pelvic limbs, vaginal delivery may be possible, but as for CSCM, it is important to consider foetal pain and potential fracture when repositioning the foetus (Figure 5). The preferred method of intervention is caesarean section or foetotomy.

sec.title: Anasarca and Hydrops Foetalis
sec.p: Anasarca is defined as a state of generalised oedema with accumulation of serum (fluid) in the connective tissue. The term is often used interchangeably with hydrops foetalis (OMIA: 000493‐9913), a condition involving serious and extensive oedema of the foetus (Merriam Webster Dictionary), but hydrops foetalis indicates the presence of an excessive amount of fluid in the body cavities, especially in the abdomen (ascites).

A specific disease entity termed pulmonary hypoplasia and anasarca (PHA, OMIA: 001562‐9913) requires special attention. This occurs sporadically across breeds in foetuses with an extra chromosome 20 (trisomy 20), but rare recessive Mendelian forms of PHA have been reported in Slovenian Cika, Dexter, Shorthorn and Maine‐Anjou cattle (Häfliger, Agerholm, et al. 2020; Häfliger, Wiedemar, et al. 2020; Whitlock et al. 2008). Pulmonary hypoplasia and anasarca is associated with an excessive accumulation of fluid in the subcutaneous tissue, which gives the foetus a monstrous appearance (Figure 7) (Agerholm and Arnbjerg 2011; Windsor et al. 2006). Reported cases have died prematurely and abortion has been initiated, but the increased size of the foetus hinders its entrance into the pelvic canal. As a consequence, the dead foetus is retained (often unnoticed) in the uterus, where it undergoes degradation causing maternal intoxication. Summarised data from the few cases reported a maternal death rate of 33% (Windsor et al. 2006).

caption.p: Pulmonary Hypoplasia and Anasarca (PHA). The extensive subcutaneous oedema characteristic of this lethal syndrome prevents foetal entrance into the pelvic canal. Some cases may die prematurely. Adapted from Agerholm and Arnbjerg (2011).

sec.p: Early recognition of a cow aborting a PHA‐affected foetus is important for the maternal prognosis. Palpation of a foetus with extensive cutaneous swelling should lead to a suspicion of PHA. Caesarean sections have been used in reported cases not otherwise euthanised due to poor prognosis.

sec.title: Hydrallantois and Hydramnion
sec.p: Hydrallantois is a life‐threatening condition characterised by an excessive accumulation of fluid in the allantoic cavity. The condition, which is usually recognised due to maternal abdominal distension (Figure 8; Hillman and Gilbert 2008; Peek 2007), is primarily associated with placental dysfunction (Constant et al. 2006). Hydrallantois can be observed in cows carrying twin foetuses, cows with severe nutritional deficiencies, cows poisoned by Sida carpinifolia , and in pregnancies originating from an in vitro manipulated embryo (Hasler et al. 1995; Reis et al. 2019; van Wagtendonk‐de Leeuw et al. 1998). In addition, an autosomal recessively inherited form has been reported in Japanese Black cattle (OMIA:002444‐9913) (Sasaki et al. 2016). Japanese Black cows affected by the inherited form of hydrallantois have allantoic fluid volumes exceeding 100 L (Sasaki et al. 2016). A recent familial occurrence of hydrallantois in North American Simmentals was reported in a pattern suggesting a maternally imprinted dominant inheritance (unpublished data; Steffen and Petersen 2025). When allowed to go near term, these cows have been found to have over 100 L of allantoic fluid present (Steffen, personal observation).

caption.p: Abdominal distension in a pregnant cow due to excessive accumulation of fluid in the amniotic and/or allantoic cavities.

sec.p: Cows with hydrallantois usually present in poor condition and distressed. If allowed to progress, abdominal tearing can occur. The increasing volume of fluid in the allantoic cavity gradually causes abdominal distension of the dam (Figure 8) and an abnormally distended uterus can be detected by transrectal palpation. The foetus is located anteriorly in the uterus, low in the abdomen, and can be hard to reach transrectally (Drost 2007). Early induction of parturition when hydrallantois is first detected can allow the dam to recover. The location of the foetus and chronic overstretching of the myometrium due to the excessive fluid volume may cause primary uterine inertia and prevent cervical dilation. A caesarean section may be the only way to deliver the foetus, which is generally not viable. Salvage slaughter may be used as an alternative.

Hydramnion is a condition characterised by an excessive accumulation of fluid in the amniotic sac (Peek 2007). This rare condition co‐exists with hydrallantois in approximately 10% of cases (Hillman and Gilbert 2008). Hydramnion is typically caused by foetal abnormalities that prevent the foetus from swallowing or properly transporting amniotic fluid through the intestines (Hillman and Gilbert 2008; Peek 2007). In cases of hydramnion, the amniotic fluid volume ranges from 19 to 114 L (Hillman and Gilbert 2008; Peek 2007). The primary clinical sign of hydramnion is gradual abdominal distension, which may resemble a twin pregnancy (Peek 2007). Cows with hydramnion often do not show overt clinical signs due to the gradual increase in fluid volume (Peek 2007). Treatment options may include induced parturition or caesarean section, depending on the severity of the condition and the stage of gestation (Hopper 2015; Zdunczyk and Grunert 1999). The prognosis for the dam's future reproductive performance is generally good (Peek 2007; Richman 1952; Zdunczyk and Grunert 1999), but the affected foetus is usually defective and rarely survives (Hillman and Gilbert 2008; Peek 2007).

sec.title: Developmental Duplications
sec.p: Developmental or embryonic duplications of relevance to bovine obstetrics usually refer to supernumerary limbs or partial duplication/splitting of the axial skeleton.

Supernumerary limbs (polymelia) may occur as thoracic limbs and as pelvic limbs, and develop as a single, two or multiple limbs. The limbs present as rudimentary structures and may appear as a simple anatomical structure or as a more complex malformation, sometimes involving other structures (syndromic duplication) (Figure 9). Supernumerary limbs are classified according to their anatomical location (Table 2).

caption.p: Supernumerary limbs. (a) Notomelia: A supernumerary thoracic limb is attached near the dorsal midline. (b) Pygomelia: Two supernumerary pelvic limbs are attached to the pelvis. Supernumerary limbs may interfere with the progression of the foetus through the birth canal. Pygomelia is of particular significance if the foetus is in posterior presentation.

tr.td: A supernumerary limb is attached at or near the dorsal midline, which corresponds to the region of the embryological notochord
A supernumerary limb is attached to the head
A supernumerary limb is attached to the thorax below the dorsal midline
A supernumerary limb is attached to the pelvis (also see dipygus)
The most severe form of pygomelia, where the supernumerary limb is associated with gastrointestinal, genitourinary and distal neural tube malformations

sec.p: The significance of the duplication depends on the anatomical location and size of the duplicate structure, the presentation of the foetus, and the foetomaternal proportion. Supernumerary thoracic limbs rooting on the head, in the dorsal midline, or on the thorax may interfere with the progression of the foetus through the birth canal, especially when the foetus is in anterior presentation. Unless the foetus can be delivered by vaginal manipulation, such foetuses should be delivered by caesarean section. If the foetus is dead, a foetotomy to transect the supernumerary limb may be the procedure of choice. Supernumerary pelvic limbs are of particular concern if the foetus is in posterior presentation. In pygomelia, where one or two limbs are present as simple structures (Figure 9), the foetus may have normal posture of the two normally developed pelvic limbs, but the supernumerary limb may be caught at an unfavourable angle inside the uterus and potentially cause uterine laceration. If supernumerary limbs are present as part of a large mass (dipygus), this may interfere with the foetal posture, e.g., resulting in hip flexion, or cause a dystocia in itself.

A recessive allele causing polymelia was proposed for Angus cattle in Australia and later, when the still unpublished causal missense variant in the NHLRC2 gene was identified, the condition was renamed developmental duplications (OMIA 002103‐9913) (Denholm and Martin 2011). It is important to note that this particular variant in the NHLRC2 gene in cattle represents a significant milestone in molecular biology. This is the first instance of a genetic variant found to be causally associated with a high incidence of conjoined twins being described at the molecular level in any species.

Duplication of the axial skeleton may affect either the anterior or posterior part of the foetus or both poles may be included in the malformation. Many cases are characterised as conjoined symmetrical twins and named according to the fused structures followed by the suffix “‐pagus”, although this terminology is not used consistently. Additional descriptive terms are added to characterise the defect, e.g., dibrachius, tribrachius and tetrabrachius for two, three and four thoracic limbs, respectively.

The obstetrical significance of craniofacial duplication (diprosopia) depends on the extent of the duplication and the size of the maternal birth canal and is mainly of importance in foetuses in anterior presentation. Diprosopia can be classified into five grades (A–E) depending on which structures are duplicated (Table 3; Hiraga et al. 1989; McNulty et al. 2023); examples showing increased levels of separation are shown in Figure 10.

caption.p: Morphological classification of craniofacial duplication based on the number of certain structures. Adapted from Hiraga et al. (1989) and McNulty et al. (2023).

Craniofacial duplication (diprosopia). The level of duplication varies among cases, as illustrated by the three cases shown (a–c). The risk of dystocia increases with an increased level of duplication as the size of the head also increases.

sec.p: Duplication of the head (dicephalus) is an important cause of dystocia. In this syndrome, two separate heads and necks develop attached to a common body (Figure 11). Dicephalus can be further categorised as iniodymus (two skulls with fusion at the occipital region), atlodymus (two skulls, one neck), or derodymus (two skulls, two necks) (McNulty et al. 2023). When the foetus is in anterior presentation, only one of the heads passes into the birth canal, while the other deviates and causes dystocia. The condition can be diagnosed by transvaginal palpation but must be differentiated from twin foetus collision by recognising the shared body. Dicephalic twins must be delivered by caesarean section if alive, but if the foetus is dead then removal of one head and neck by foetotomy may be a less invasive procedure. Euthanasia of calves delivered live must be by lethal injection, as each brain functions independently and can sense pain and distress.

caption.p: Embryonic duplication. Symmetrical conjoined twinning is invariably associated with dystocia in cattle. While a condition like dicephalus with two necks (derodymus; a) may be managed by foetotomy, embryonic duplication involving larger body parts usually requires caesarean section; (b) Thoracopagus: The foetuses are conjoined at the sternal region; (c) Parapagus: There are two separate spines, two heads and four thoracic limbs. The foetuses are joined in the abdominal region and only two pelvic limbs are present; (d) Omphalopagus: The twins are conjoined in the abdominal region with two heads, two spines and two sets of thoracic and pelvic limbs.

sec.p: Complete or partial duplication of the trunk results in a large increase in foetal size (Figure 11). Vaginal delivery is usually not possible and caesarean section should be performed. However, given the large size of the foetus, emergency slaughter should be discussed with the breeder. In the case of an emphysematous foetus, euthanasia of the dam may be the best solution from both an animal welfare and a financial perspective. The cause of duplication of the axial skeleton is not known.

sec.title: Enlargement of the Calvarium
sec.p: Enlargement of the calvarium develops either due to expansion caused by increased intracranial pressure, as in hydrocephalus (Figure 12), or due to communication of the ventricular system with the subcutaneous tissue through a defect in the bone, as in meningocele and meningoencephalocele (Figure 13; Gentile et al. 2021). Some cases of hydranencephaly, a condition resulting from extensive loss of cerebral tissue and its replacement by cerebrospinal fluid, may also show some enlargement of the calvarium. Although very rare, other conditions such as congenital tumours have also been found (Jacinto et al. 2021; Veiga et al. 2017).

caption.p: Hydrocephalus. Severe hydrocephalus may increase the size of the foetal calvarium or present as a cerebrospinal fluid‐filled sac protruding from the forehead. (a) External appearance of a case of severe hydrocephalus. (b) Longitudinal mid‐plane section of a frozen specimen. The frontal bones (arrowheads) are included in the lower part of the structure as flat, partly cartilaginous bone plates. Evacuation of the cerebrospinal fluid through an incision will cause collapse of the structure to the level indicated by the dotted line.
Meningocele. Like hydrocephalus, meningocele may cause dystocia if the saccular structure is of a size that interferes with the posture of the head or the foetus' progression through the birth canal.

sec.p: Hydrocephalus (OMIA: 000487‐9913) can have a number of causes. In some cases, hydrocephalus develops as an isolated condition, but in other cases, hydrocephalus is a part of a complex malformation involving organs other than the brain (syndromic hydrocephalus). Hydrocephalus develops due to increased pressure in the ventricular system leading to atrophy of the cerebrum, sometimes due to insufficient drainage of cerebrospinal fluid through the mesencephalic duct. The aetiology leading to hydrocephalus remains unknown in most cases, but genetic and viral causes have been identified. A condition known as neuropathic hydrocephalus has been reported in Angus, Shorthorn and Jersey cattle, shown to be due to a recessive allele, although details reporting the causal variant have not been published in the scientific literature (American Angus Association 2019; Denholm et al. 2014). This condition causes a severe form of hydrocephalus with extensive enlargement of the calvarium. The cranial symphyses in the Angus phenotype are not well formed and the body size is reduced due to muscle hypoplasia. These calves are most often dead and may be manipulated for vaginal delivery. Hydrocephalus is also a well‐known consequence of foetal infection with bovine viral diarrhoea virus, Orthobunyaviruses (e.g., Schmallenberg virus, Aino virus, Shuni virus, Peaton virus and Shamonda virus) and bluetongue virus (Agerholm et al. 2015; Agerholm and Wernike 2022; O'Connor et al. 2024).

Meningocele and meningoencephalocele develop as saccular cerebrospinal fluid‐filled protrusions from the surface of the head, often covered by skin. The underlying lesion is a defect in the neurocranium (cranioschisis; OMIA: 000237‐9913). Such protrusions are most significant if they are large and extend through the frontal bone region (Figure 13) as this location is more likely to interfere with the passing of the foetus through the birth canal than in cases where the structure originates from the occipital bone region. The aetiology leading to meningocele and meningoencephalocele in cattle remains unknown.

The obstetrical significance of hydrocephalus and meningo(encephalo)cele depends on the size of the head compared to the dimensions of the maternal birth canal, as well as on the presentation of the foetus. A diagnosis can be achieved by transvaginal palpation if the foetus is in anterior presentation, and the enlarged calvarium can be reduced in size by incision (using a finger knife) and evacuation of the cerebrospinal fluid. This will reduce the size of the structure, which in combination with compression of the usually flat and thin frontal bones (Figure 12) may reduce the size sufficiently to allow vaginal delivery. If the foetus is in posterior presentation, it may only advance until the voluminous structure meets the pelvic inlet and hinders further progression of the parturition. This severe complication may require excision of the available parts of the foetus, followed by transvaginal manipulation and handling of the anterior parts of the foetus.

sec.title: Future Fertility Implications
sec.p: In brief, the future fertility of a cow that has been pregnant with a malformed foetus depends on two factors: (1) the risk of giving birth to a similar case in future pregnancies and (2) the significance of disorders developing as a complication of abnormal gestation and dystocia.

The risk of giving birth to a similar case is closely associated with the cause of the malformation. However, with the exception of infectious causes, specific knowledge on the cause is generally not available. The general advice is therefore not to re‐breed the cow with the same sire, one of his close relatives or with a sire genetically related to the cow in order to reduce the risk of transmission of a possible harmful paternal allele. If the congenital malformation is thought to be due to a characterised genetic condition, it may also be possible to avoid breeding with a heterozygous sire by requesting genotyping information from the breeding company before breeding. The risk of encountering additional cases of a specific defect can be reduced by taking these simple precautions.

Infection with the teratogenic Schmallenberg virus is only considered an issue for immunologically naïve dams (Wernike et al. 2018). Protective antibodies against this virus develop after initial exposure and persist in the majority of cattle for at least 6 years, if not for their remaining lifetime (Wernike et al. 2018). Also, for other viruses such as blue tongue virus, year‐long immunity is expected upon maternal exposure (Batten et al. 2013). The risk of giving birth to an additional malformed foetus if the dam is exposed repeatedly is therefore considered minimal for most dams.

Complications with an abnormal gestation and dystocia are more important for future fertility than the risk of giving birth to an additional malformed foetus. Dystocia is a well‐known risk factor for developing postpartum uterine diseases such as metritis and purulent vaginal discharge (Dubuc et al. 2010), conditions that have a negative impact on fertility (LeBlanc 2023). Data on the impact of individual congenital syndromes on future fertility are limited, but as it is the dystocia that impacts the fertility rather than the specific malformation, an equivalent negative impact is expected. Fluid accumulation syndromes such as hydrallantois and hydramnion cause prolonged overstretching of the myometrium leading to primary uterine inertia, a risk factor for developing metritis. The prognosis for future fertility is guarded in such cases (House 2020).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Despite centuries of improvements in cattle breeding and management that have reduced the negative impact of dystocia on animal health and welfare and farm economy, dystocia due to developmental disorders still presents a challenge to bovine breeders and veterinary practitioners. While methods of intervention in these cases have remained unchanged for decades, advances in genetic and aetiologic understanding have broadened our knowledge of the causes of these congenital syndromes. Where simple recessive alleles have been identified, selection against these deleterious gene variants is indicated to reduce the prevalence. Genomic evaluation of suspected germline mosaic sires producing several similarly affected progenies is recommended prior to any further use of semen from these bulls. Genotyping and breeding restrictions on the carriers of recessively transmitted disorders can reduce the significance of some disorders, but as shown in this review, many are due to de novo mutations, which cannot be prevented by breeding strategies or are the result of foetal exposure to a teratogenic virus. Such causes of dystocia will continue in the future, and veterinary practitioners must therefore be familiar with the most frequently occurring conditions as presented in this review. Breed organisations, semen distributors and some governments have programmes to investigate emerging potentially heritable diseases. It is important to report occurrences of abnormal calves from pedigreed sires for investigation prior to disposal. Collecting images, saving tissues and arranging for sampling to establish diagnosis are critical to advancing science and limiting future losses.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Jørgen S. Agerholm: conceptualisation, writing – original draft. Cord Drögemüller: writing – review and editing. David J. Steffen: writing – review and editing. Joana G. P. Jacinto: writing – original draft, review and editing.

sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
